text: hey folks before we get into today's

the world's most innovative senior

learn more about the events at
cueconferences.com
we hope to see you there

technical director for engineering
enablement
sounds very much like building that

in the first quarter of 2021 at the
financial times we moved some teams
around to make sure that every team that
built things for
engineers all were part of my group so
that meant that things like cyber
security engineering and cloud platforms
that i had not had in my area when i was
tech director of operations reliability
moved in what that allowed us to do is
to look at what is that paved road we
talk about it as the golden path a lot
of the financial times but the idea is
that you have a path that people don't
have to follow but they should want to
follow it because it's easier than
hacking through the jungle you make it
something that's really attractive and
easy to use and you look where people go
off that path because if lots of people
are going off that path maybe actually
you haven't made it as easy as you
thought so there's obviously some things
where you can't let people go and just
choose their own approach there are
always some considerations around
security or cost or just complexity or
you know operational concerns so for
example i wouldn't really like to have
people using different log aggregation
tools in the same company because i'd
like to be able to follow a request
across all teams and not have to jump
out into different tooling there might
be cases where that's really good but
maybe for a local improvement you're
losing something globally so i think
engineering enablement is about can you
pave that road and can you also try and
kind of argue the case for some things
should be a little more standardized
that's what i've been doing for this
last year and there's a lot to it
there's a lot of things there that are
really interesting
because you're always trying to balance
what you're trying to achieve product
development teams want to build their
product
let's explore some of those balances and
when it starts to go even outside of the
development teams the development
environment there are business
trade-offs that we have to make and how
do you pave that road yeah so one thing
that was interesting to me as i started
to get more involved with the
relationships with our cloud vendors
with the cloud platform is the
realization that you know people tend to
assume
that a team in charge of that is mostly
focused on costs and cost control but i
think there's always a balance there's
always a balance between do we want to
spend more money on our platform because
we're building more stuff and we're
selling more stuff so an example for
this would be when the pandemic started
the financial times made a lot of their
coronavirus coverage free and it's great
coverage i mean the infographics on this
are exceptional and we got a lot of
people coming to read it so that means
there's a lot more traffic to the
website and the interesting conversation
that led to was well we end up paying
more for our cdn we end up paying more
for log aggregation we have lots of
things where there is a cost to serve a
customer so you have to have a
conversation with parts of the business
outside of product and technology so a
finance department you need to explain
how cloud platforms work i think it's
quite often looked at as a cost center
you have to make the case that it's not
a cross center you want to spend more
money if you're building products that
people will then want to subscribe to so
i think there's some interesting things
there it's a credit i think to our
engineering team that our editorial team
didn't really worry about making lots of
things free to view when i first joined
the ft i think we talked a lot about can
the site take this traffic if a big
thing happens we've got so much more
sort of flexibility and scalability the
editorial don't really think about that
in that way anymore but they're always
consequences of your editorial decisions
yeah and just on a personal note that ft

what does it take
to
bring the typically i'm going to be a

cannon
developers who really are incredibly

this paved road i think it's interesting
you have some developers who want to do

to turn their hands to a lot of things
i've heard simon wardley talk about
pioneers settlers and town planners the
pioneers people are out there building
something new and they might be quite
hacked together and held together with
sticking tape and then the settlers come
in and they kind of make it a bit more
solid and town planners it's like you're
continuing to do work within something
that's very quite regimented i think
that probably five years ago we had a
lot of people doing pioneering work at
the ft and as people came in to make it
more solid the settlers came in actually
there were lots of things they didn't
want to do they would that you find the
things that actually aren't interesting
and valuable lots of developers want to
focus their efforts on stuff that solves
problems for the business so they
probably don't want to have to maintain
their own cloud platform or ship logs
somewhere different because that's a
local improvement that you've done so i
think you find the things that are
pretty common and that not everybody
wants to know about but you have to make
the case that there are some things
where you lose out if it's a complete
free choice for everything and so what
we talked about a lot of the ft is
building a golden path or a paved road
so the idea is you pick a set of tools
and approaches and you make them easy to
use and that's typically building as
little as possible of a layer between
the vendor and people using it so that
you don't abstract away useful stuff but
you just make it really easy for people
to do the things they need a lot of ft's
built on aws you put some tooling around
some of the aws stuff so that people can
easily deploy resources
so you pave out the road you document it
really well because actually you want
your product development engineers to be
able to do like the 80 of standard stuff
without talking to you they're just
going to read the documentation use your
tools do it they can move fast they're
not held up and then you make sure that
if they get stuck on something you're
very responsive and you're solving their
problems for them and if it starts to
come up a lot you start adding that to
the paper and the idea is that people
can go off-road but it should be much
easier to go along the road than to hack
through the jungle if people are
starting to hack through the jungle then
maybe actually you haven't solved a
problem the way that they need it so you
need to be responsive to your customers
so it's kind of engineering enablement
you have to understand that you're also
building a product and your customers
are engineers so you'd use the same
tools to talk to your customers and work
out where their problems are and how you
might solve it and you have the same
problems of people telling you this
would solve their problem but actually
you need them to step back and tell you
what the actual problem is so i think
there's a lot of you know persuasion you
want to try and avoid too much mandating
because engineers don't tend to respond
well to being told you must do this but
you can obviously explain to people it's
too costly for us to have multiple of
these things in play so how does this
grow out to that broader developer
experience that we touched on earlier i
think if you want engineers to use the
things you build you need to be thinking
about how you make those into an
enjoyable experience you want people to
come to you and say this thing is so
useful i can't imagine not having it
when i saw that happening at the
financial times there's a really lovely
culture there where people will say i
love this tool it's so great and if
you're in a slack channel and someone
says this is useful to me multiple times
a week then you go hey we've hit
something there and then you know
there's the flip side of this is
annoying um you need to be responsive
and say okay why is it annoying but i do
think that developer experience is
really important because the key to
actually building good stuff is that
your developers are able to focus on the
business problem and not be held up by
everything else there's something really
frustrating about i just want to make
this one change i've got to do all these
other things to get there that yak
shaving thing like if you google yak
shaving it's great it's like the idea
that you know you need to do this thing
but to do that you do something else and
you need to have something else and
eventually you find yourself shaving a
yak to get the fur to stop percussion so
there's just a i recognize it and if you
can take away some of those steps and
allow people to keep the focus on the
thing they're actually trying to achieve
you're going to make their life easier
and happier and more productive
i want to be skeptical and say but this

make it hard for you to do something

and advice for leaders people maybe the
newly minted leader you've been through
that and got to that position of
technical director but somebody earlier
in their career who are moving perhaps
into
a team leadership or
that sort of a role some sage advice so
one of the first things that i say to
anyone that is becoming a tech lead for
the first time is your job is not to
code anymore because often you're a
really good developer and then you
become a tech lead and you don't want to
give up the coding and you shouldn't
give up the coding but you need to make
sure that you're not on the critical
path for anything because you will get
pulled aside you'll be dealing with
something you'll have a meeting there'll
be an emergency something like that and
if you're the person who is building the
core thing that you're delivering this
week that is a problem so what you end
up doing what i ended up doing when i
first was a tech lead was you find the
little annoying things around the edges
so you end up building team tooling and
things that there's not a deadline but
it's quite nice to tidy up and improve
so that's a good place to keep your tech
skills there but you also just need to
be aware that's not your job anymore
your job is to coach and mentor other
people and to have a view of what your
tech estate is and what makes sense to
do in that and i think the second thing
i would say is your life is better if
you spend time communicating to people
outside of engineering about what you're
trying to do and think about why you're
doing it not just for engineers so for
example you've always got a number of
things you need to do for what people
generally say tech debt you know there's
always some level of tactics but you
have to kind of explain it in terms of
why do we need to actually do this so it
could be we need to upgrade the database
because you need to upgrade databases
and if we don't do it there's a security
risk or we're getting really slow at
delivering value because this area is
very complicated we didn't get it right
so helping to explain to the people
around you that that it's natural to go
back and redo things but having an
ability to recognize that the business
don't really care what database you're
using probably so they just hear you
saying names and words and so basically
try and have empathy
with the people that you work with to
explain what your team is doing because
i think your job as a leader is to make
it easy for your team to be able to do
the right things and some of that is
about selling your team and selling what
they're doing so that you can keep going
so i think there's a natural distrust of
having to sell things as an engineer i
certainly had it but if you ask people
they're generally proud about the stuff
that they do so you have to speak up
about it because that is what gives you
the space to do the next thing you want
to do one of the things that i've heard
more than once is that when you move out
of the
individual contributor role into those
leadership roles and in my own
experience this has definitely been the
case there is value in actually starting
to share your knowledge what do you feel
about that absolutely i think that it's
important in general like it's important
for your team that you can share what
you know it's also i think something
where if you can start to
write about the things that you know or
speak about them you really help put all
of that together into a coherent train
of thought i started speaking when i was
a tech lead and it's a lot of work to
put together a talk but after you've
done it you kind of have something to
draw on that's your opinion on this
subject and i think that like the
ability to put together a story or an
argument about something is a really
good skill it's a great skill as a
leader the ability to tell a story that
can persuade people into a particular
direction so
i honestly think that a leader's job is
generally to say have you spoken to um
so-and-so about this and just keep
saying that repeatedly because talking
to other people is a good thing but also
just can you put together one page of
why this is important and you quite
often get pushback from people but i
think if you're really keen on doing
something and the idea of writing one
page to explain it is putting you off
i'm not convinced that you've really
thought it through we used to do 10 time
when i was in the content platform at
the financial time so
one day a fortnight you could if you
wanted go and spend a day doing whatever
you liked that would help your team or
the ft and explore something in
technology so the only things that we
said were you need to tell us in advance
what you're going to do and you need to
present back the day afterwards just to
five minutes and the reason we did that
was because i think it can be really
easy for people to just start putting on
a thread and just not quite do anything
concrete it's much better if you can say
well i am going to try and install this
software and try and and it was
absolutely fine for the next day to say
i just didn't get anywhere because it
was actually really difficult to use and
there were a couple of things that were
really great about this one was that
people got used to just presenting back
the things that they'd been doing
another was that if you got into a
discussion with people about a
particular thing in technology in your
team and they were like i think we
should try this thing you could say well
do you want to try it out in 10 times
and sometimes they try it out and it
would be great and you'd adopt it and
often they try it out and they would say
after a day of investigating yeah it's
not as good as i thought it was and both
those ways you've got a lot of value and
you haven't spent weeks arguing about it
but so i think there's something really
good about trying to put together a case
a very
lightweight case for
doing something it makes you put your
thoughts in order and spreading even
further you're a pretty regular speaker
now what does it take to get there
well
i think
in the first case
my boss suggested i put in a proposal
for a conference and i thought well you
know i'll put in a proposal i'm not
expecting to be accepted and i've
encouraged a couple of people that work
with me to do something similar if you
want to just start speaking setting
yourself the target of i am going to

scary as i'm gonna talk and if you get

then after that i said yes a lot
initially so i said yes to repeating my
talk that i think i submitted the same
talk to a second conference very soon
after because i thought if the first one

it a second time so you know there's a
chance that i'll fix that up and i just
found it really there was so much
rewarding about it i felt like i really
understood the topic after i'd written a

up and talk to you about it at the

learn a huge amount from that and then
you meet other speakers and find a lot
out from them and the network of people
that i had met for example when i
started being a tech director i could
often find someone that i knew another
company and say you use this technology
how does that work for you and people
are quite willing generally to say this
is our experience and to share stuff so
i found that network incredibly valuable
in helping me to make progress more
quickly than if we tried to solve
everything from scratch and you know a
trivial example would be it's not
trivial but one example we were thinking
about trying to manage our operational
incidents in slack and we were speaking
about oh maybe we should write a sackbot
for that and i knew that monzo had a
sackbot and they'd open sourced it and
we just decided we would just use this
we spoke to the people at monzo a little
bit about it and then we just installed

changes as we discovered things that
were different for us it just got us
going really quickly and we knew it
would work for them we knew about it
because we had that connection with

i used to often feel like i was talking
